sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: The FRDCSA project is concerned with implementing a public domain AI out of existing available free software.
We define AI to be "the evasion of chance in survival". This is achieved by being able to solve relatively greater classes of problems.

sect1.title: Call for Assistance
sect1.para: The first thing we suggest is understanding the relevance of this project to your daily life.

By contributing to this project you will be able to help eliminate systematic ignorance that results from lack of problem solving capabilities. Our goal is to reach as many people as possible, and gain a reputation as an organization which promotes an objective problem solving approach that helps people solve the conflicts of interest that result from the inability to solve certain problems due to bounded rationality. Then, people will become more accepting as we assist them in resolving outstanding problems that negatively affect their welfare and quality of life.

sect1.title: Commandments
sect1.para: Starting from this point on, you will become educated as to our general methods for resolving problems. In the future, more robust, intelligent interfaces will be finished which will be far more useful than this simple documentation, but for the purposes of having a starting point this documentation exists.
In order to succeed with this system you must read this entire manual.

Consider that when a person reads a manual, there are at least two kind of concepts that they learn. Let us define "justified" concepts as those which the user has sufficient knowledge to correctly accept or reject. Conversely, define "unjustified" concepts to be those which the user lacks the ability to correctly accept or reject.

The concepts here are often of the "unjustified" sort. There are various common psychological reactions to learning of unjustified concepts, some of which result in understanding and some of which don't.

The best strategy is to treat unjustified concepts as assertions whose meaning is not know currently, and then to bind meaning to them as one sees co-occurances of them in the text. Then, when their meaning becomes completely clear, a person can then decide whether they are incorrect.

Unjustified are usually the most novel and informative, and therefore it is in the readers interest to study further despite being unsure of the meaning of the concepts, so that eventually, all unjustified concepts have been so thoroughly explained that they have become justified concepts, which the user can then make an informed decision. But until all reading has finished, the user lacks the correct language to understand the concepts.
